name: C1_1
probTex: Prove that a Riemann surface $M$ is orientable.
solnTex:
Recall that $M$ is orientable if we are able to choose local coordinates $\{U, \tilde{\varphi} \}$, $\{V, \varphi \}$ such that $\det(J(\tilde{\varphi} \circ \varphi^{-1})) > 0$ for all transition functions $\tilde{\varphi} \circ \varphi^{-1}$. We can write the transition maps as $\tilde{\varphi} \circ \varphi^{-1} = \mu(x,y) + i 
u(x,y)$. The Jacobian is a $2$ by $2$ matrix so we have
\[N := J(\tilde{\varphi} \circ \varphi^{-1}) = \left[ {\begin{array}{cc} \frac{\partial\mu}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial \mu}{\partial y} \\ \frac{\partial
u}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial
u}{\partial y} \\ \end{array} } \right]\]
First, note that since $M$ is a Riemann surface, the transition functions are holomorphic and therefore satisfy the Cauchy Riemann equations. Second, note that transition maps are nonsingular so the determinant is nonzero. Then we get 
\[\det(N) = \frac{\partial\mu}{\partial x}\frac{\partial
u}{\partial y} - \frac{\partial\mu}{\partial y}\frac{\partial
u}{\partial x} = \left(\frac{\partial \mu}{\partial x}\right)^2 + \left(\frac{\partial\mu}{\partial y}\right)^2 > 0 \]
 Hence $M$ is orientable.
